Beyond the Mini -Mental State Examination : the use of physical and s patial navigation tests to help to screen for mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer ’s disease Jessica Plácido (orcid.org/0000 -0003 -1921 -6672), José Vinicius Ferreiraa, Juliana Araújoa, Felipe de Oliveira Silva (orcid.org/0000 -0002 -1457 -0480), Renan Baltar Ferreira Andréa Nunes de Carvalho (orcid.org/0000 -0002 -8294 -4552) , Jerson Laks , Andrea Camaz
Estudo aceito pela Jornal of A lzheimer’s Disease em março de 2021

ABSTRACT BACKGROUND : Spatial navigation and dual -task (DT) performance may represent a low - cost approach to the identification of the cognitive decline in older adults and may support the clinical diag nosis of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). OBJECTIVE : To assess the accuracy of different types of motor tasks in differentiating older persons with MCI and AD from healthy peers.

METHODS: older adults aged 60 years or over ( n=105; healthy = 39; MCI = 23; AD = 43) were evaluated by the floor maze test (FMT), the senior fitness test, and DT performance . Receiver operating characteristic curve (ROC) analysis was used to evaluate the accuracy of the tests. We also performed principa l component analysis (PCA) and logistic regression analysis to explore the variance and possible associations of the variables within the sample. RESULTS: FMT (AUC = 0.84, sensitivity = 75.7%, specificity = 76.1%, P < 0.001 ) and DT (AUC = 0.87, sensitivity = 80.4%, specificity = 86.9%, P < 0.001) showed the highest performance for distinguishing MCI from AD individuals . Moreover , FMT presented better sensitivity in distinguishing AD patients from their healthy peers (AUC = 0.93, sensitivity = 94%, specifici ty = 85.6%, P < 0.001) when compared to the Mini -Mental State Examination (MMSE). PCA revealed that the motor test performance explain s a total of 73.9% of the variance of the sample. Additionally, the results of the motor tests were not influenced by age and education.

CONCLUSION: Spatial navigation tests showed better accuracy than usual cognitive screening tests in distinguishing patients with neurocognitive disorders. Keywords : Biomarkers, Alzheimer’s Disease, Mild Cognitive Impairment, Physical Fitness , Aerobic Capacity, Dual -Task, Spatial Navigation, Floor Maze Test

INTRODUCTION Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia worldwide, affecting more than 30 million older adults, and the number is expected to triple in the next 40 years (Barnes e Yaffe, 2011) . This increase is predicted to occur mainly in low - and middle -income countries, also contributing to the increase of poor health and disability within these populations (Wimo et al. , 2017; Association, 2018) . AD is associated with a high economic burden , with an estimated cost of nearly one trillion dollars per year (Wimo et al. , 2017) . It is important to investigate the preclinical stages of the disease to find an effective means of identifying older adults at risk of cognitiv e disorders, including mild cognitive impairment (MCI). According to the Alzheimer’s Association Report published in 2018 (Association, 2018) , early diagnosis of AD could save up to $7.9 billion in medical and care costs per year. This highlights the impor tance of finding possible biomarkers to increase diagnostic accuracy and predict disease progression. This information can then be used to develop and implement public health strategies designed to decrease the impact of dementia.

According to the Biomarke rs Definitions Working Group , biomarkers must provide high sensitivity (>80%), specificity (>80%) and positive predictive values (>80%) (Group et al., 2001; El Kadmiri et al. , 2018) . In addition, to ensure that the diagnoses are not missed after an initial assessment, a brief screening test has been suggested to selectively increas e the sensitivity of the current tests over specificity. This approach would also be beneficial in avoiding a false negative result, which may cause a delay in providing a correct diagnosis (Hampel et al. , 2010; Breton et al. , 2019) . Bradford et al. (2009) reported that approximately 81% of the subjects with dementia are not diagnosed as such and, therefore, do not receive the appropriate treatment for the disease. Currently, the m ost commonly used biomarkers of AD are brain amyloid -beta peptide (Aβ) and hyperphosphorylated Tau (T -tau) protein (Dumurgier et al. , 2017) . However , the large intra - and inter -laboratory variations in the measurement of these proteins, as well as, the hig h cost and the absence of defined cut -off points are some of the factors that hinder the clinical use of these biomarkers, which are currently recommended for research use only (Mattsson et al. , 2013; Olsson et al. , 2016; Dumurgier et al. , 2017) . On the ot her hand, cognitive tests, despite being easy -to-apply and an ecological option due to its low cost, are often influenced by confoundi ng variables (Tsoi et al. , 2015; Santiago -Bravo et

Recently, the subcommittee of the Canadian Consensus Confer ence on Diagnosis and Treatment of Dementia (CCCDTD) concluded , through a literature review, that there is strong evidence to support that gait speed can be considered an early biomarker of dementia, and that routine monitoring of gait performance in prima ry care and specialized clinics can assist in identifying older persons at risk for cognitive decline or dementia, especially, in dual -task (DT) condition (Montero‐Odasso et al. , 2020) . Based on the models of capacity -sharing, bottleneck and multiple resources, tasks requiring the simultaneous use of cognitive and motor skills may represent even more sensitive than those involving single motor actions due to an increase of performance costs and mental workload (Wickens, 2008; Strobach et al. , 2018) . Montero - Odasso et al. (2017) investigated the incidence of dementia in individuals with MCI through the use of a dual-task (DT) gait testing. They concluded that older persons with the worst performances in these tests were up to three times more likely to progress to dementia, even after controlling for the genetic load of APOE ε4 . Spatial navigation is another task that seems to be sensitive to changes in MCI and AD (Tangen et al. , 2015; Zanco et al. , 2018) . Costa et al. (2020) showed through a systematic review that spatial orientation tasks had a moderate to high accuracy to distinguish MCI patients from healthy older persons (AUC = 0.77 to 0.99, sensitivity = 0.74 - 0.94, specificity =0.70 – 0.97). H owever, the author s emphasize the need for more studies, especially those that investigate more ecological protocols . Althou gh the processing of spatial navigation is attributed mainly to the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex, it is also a complex cognitive function, dependent on the activation of several cerebral structures such as the retrosplenial cortex, caudate nucleus, an d precuneus, as well as medial and posterior parietal areas (Colombo et al. , 2017) . Some of these regions are als o involved in motor circuits, such as those at the posterior parietal region (involved in motor planning), the caudate nucleus (movement execut ion) and the retrosplenial cortex (vestibular system). Such complexity could generate an increase in mental workload, especially when the test is performed in a real -world environment. The accuracy of these tests in such populations needs to be clarified . According to the CCCDTD, the establishment of sensitivity, specificity, predictive values and cut -off point of motor biomarkers should further enhance the utility of these tests to clinic al and medical practices (Montero‐Odasso et al. , 2020) . Since motor b iomarkers could represent a low -cost approach to the identification of cognitive decline with higher sensitivity/specificity and may aid in the clinical diagnosis of dementia, we conducted this study to assess the accuracy of different types of motor tasks in differentiating older persons with MCI and AD from their healthy peers.

MATERIAL AND METHODS The AD and MCI participants were recruited by the medical staff at the Center for Alzheimer's Disease and other Mental Disorders in Older Persons at the Instit ute of Psychiatry of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (CDA/IPUB -UFRJ). Whereas the control group was composed of caregivers, patient's family , and older adults were invited from community centers. A diagnostic assessment was performed through a str uctured clinic al interview SCID for evaluation of mental disorders , as stated in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders - Fourth Edition (Association, 2014) . Patients (>60 years old) with MCI (according to the diagnostic criteria previou sly proposed by Petersen (Petersen et al. , 2001) ) and AD were classified by applying the Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) (i.e., 0.5-1.0 (mild) , 2.0 (moderate) and 3.0 (severe) ) (Morris, 1997) . All individuals without any type of cognitive impairment, or psychiatric or neurological disorder, as confirmed by a psychiatrist in clinical interviews , using the same clinical protocol , were c onsidered healthy older persons (MMSE, CDR e DSM IV) (Folstein et al. , 1975) . The exclusion criteria were: illiteracy , cerebr al infarction , and ongoing treatments like electroconvulsive therapy and psychotherapy. Subjects with any other neurological disorders, as well as a diagnosis for other types of dementia, physical disability and visual and/or hearing impairment , were also excluded . All patients signed the written informed consent. This study was approved by the Research Ethics Committee at IPUB -UFRJ (CAAE: 24904814.0.0000.5263 ) and it is part of a broader project entitled “Efficacy of physical exercise in the treatment of M ajor Depression, Alzheimer’s Disease and Parkinson’s Disease” . Procedures and tests After the diagnostic assessments, patients with AD, MCI, and healthy older adults completed a battery of physical and cognitive tests conducted during three visits. Day 1 : Signature of the written informed consent, anamnesis, anthropometric measures, and neuropsychological tests (CDR, Trails A -B, verbal fluency, and MMSE). Day 2: A maximal treadmill test was done to predict VO 2max and assess possible cardiac health problem s (Medicine, 2000) . Day 3: physical evaluations composed by tasks of the Senior Fitness T est battery ( step test, 8-foot up-and-go test (8UG), and Sit-to-stand test (STS)) , dual -task and Floor Maze Tes t (Rikli e Jones, 1999; Sanders et al. , 2008) .
8-foot Up and Go Test (8UG)

In this test the participant should move in a straight line for 8 feet , walk around a cone and r eturn to the initial position in the shortest time. The physical abilities evaluated are speed, agility and dynamic balance.

Sit-to-stand Te st The participant had to rise to a full stand and return to a full seated position in a chair, as many times as possible within a 30 -second interval. The test was used to measure the strength of the lower limbs.

Step Test A mark was drawn on a wall or do or with the aid of tape, which corresponded to a point exactly midway between the subject’s patella and the iliac crest. After the signal to “go,” the participant had to alternate steps, without moving forward, within a given timeframe. The score recorded was the number of times the right knee reached the required height within 2 min. This test is often used in the literature to verify the cardiorespiratory resistance of a special population.

Floor Maze Test (FMT) The Floor Maze Test is a task previously de veloped by Sanders et al. (2008) that combines spatial navigation with walking and requires the individual to plan a rout ing strategy to move in a two -dimensional maze. The subjects are placed at the start ing point of the maze and receive basic orientation s about the entrance and the exit. Three stages were evaluated: Planning Time (PT), which is the time spent between the receipt of instructions and discovery of the correct way out, excluding the time spent walking; Immediate Maze Time (IMT), which is the time spent walking between the entry of the maze and the successful exit; and Delayed Maze Time (DMT ), which is the time spent on repetition of the second period, performed after 10 min without planning. During this interval, the participants were not able to maintain visual contact with the maze.

Dual task (DT) To measure the dual -task performance we used a combination of 8UG with the verbal fluency test. The subjects were instructed to perform the 8UG test in the shortest time , evoking as many animals as they could. Dual -task cost (DTC) was calculated by the following index
(DTC= ([test time in a single task - time of test performed in double task] / time of test in a single task)×100).

Statistical analysis To evaluate the normality of the data we used t he Komolgorov -Smirnov test, we also tested comparative analy ses through the One -way ANOVA -to parametric variables - and Kruskall -Wallis for the non-parametric data. Differences among the groups were investigated using the post hoc of Bonferroni and the Man n-Whitney test s. The chi -square test was used to compare the categorical variables. Composite score (CS) was calculated for single tasks; CS=(Zscore 8UG + Zscore sit to stand + ZscoreSTEP) / 3) and the FMT delta (= Delayed Maze Time -Immediate Maze Time ) was used as a retention capacity measure for spatial information. The accuracy, sensitivity and specificity of the tests were explored using the ROC curve analysis through the area under the curve (AUC), also the likelihood and the percentage of correctly cla ssified values were calculated. We use d the ratio between the proportion of true - positives and the proportion of false -positives to calculate the positive likelihood rati o (LR+), whereas the negative likelihood rati o (LR-) was obtained by dividing the prop ortion of false - negatives by the proportion of true -negative s. The optimal cutoff score was determined for each test by balancing sensitivity and specificity , according to the Youden Index score. We performed a Principal Components Analysis (PCA) to explor e the variance and possible associations of the variables inside the sample. The PCA allows multiple variables to be analyzed simultaneously, from a transformation of the original set of variables into a significantly smaller set of main components (i.e., dimensionality reduction). Then, a combination of multivariate analy ses was performed to assess the participation of variables in class discrimination (i.e., groups). The results of this application w ere based on the combination of the first two components generated, given that together, they were able to explain approximately 70% of the variability present in the data. Additionally , a multinomial logistic regression was performed to measure the test ability to correctly classify the diagnoses and identify the influence of the confounding variables (age, sex and schooling) on the performance of the tests. Only the variables considered relevant were retained in the final models for later interpretation. Statistical analysis was conducted using SPSS® software version 20.0 (IBM Corporation, New York, USA), Stata and R Studio software version 1.3.1073. The significance level considered was p ≤ 0.05.

RESULTS A total of 126 older persons were initially recruited. A total of 14 of them were excluded due to the non-availability of the caregiver (n=4), no interest to follow the research after protocol presentation (n=7) and CDR 3 (n=3). Additionally, 7 other subjects were excluded because they either present ed cardiovascular disease (which made them unable to do the physical tests ) (n=5) or psychiatric comorbidities (n=2). Thus, 105 subjects (healthy=39; MCI=23; AD=43) were included in the final sample ( Figure 1).
Figure 1: Flow chart of the selection of subjects.

The groups were different in age (<0.001), STEP test perf ormance ( p<0.001), Immediate Maze Time (p<0.001) and Delayed Maze Time (p<0.001) , and the AD group present ed worse cardiorespiratory fitness and spatial navigation performance . Additionally, time of dual -task, the number of animals evoked per second, and t he mean velocity of dual -task presented difference only between AD and healthy groups ( p<0.001) and MCI and AD (p<0.001). The AD group was significantly slower to complete the 8UG (7.6 secs) when compared to MCI (6.4 sec s) and healthy individuals (5.9 secs), they also presented a worse performance in the sit to stand test (Healthy=13rep, MCI=11rep, AD=11rep). However, there was no difference in mobility (8UG) and lower limb strength (STS) of older persons with MCI when compared to the healthy group and betw een MCI and AD (p =0.12 and p=0.41). When the cognitive variables were evaluated, difference s were observed in global cognition (MMSE) , verbal fluency (VF) and attention (Trail A) between MCI and AD and healthy and AD (p<0.001) . On the other hand, the executive function (Trail B) presented a difference among all three groups ( p=0.002) (Table 1).

ROC analys es were perfo rmed to estimate the accuracy of the test s to distinguish healthy from MCI subjects , MCI from AD and healthy from AD subjects . In the first analysis, the three stages of the FMT, STEP and CS were the tests that showed a potential to discriminate healthy from MCI individuals. CS presented the best performance (AUC= 0.79). The sensitivity and specificity values were similar for the se five tests . Conversely, t he following tests did not present significant accuracy values to discriminate the groups: MMSE (AUC =0.591 p=0.23), 8UG ( seconds ) and mean velocity (AUC=0.563 p=0.41), dual -task ( seconds ), mean velocity task cost (AUC =0.541 p=0.59) and Delta FMT (AUC =0.516 p=0.83). All significant results for this analysis are reported in Table 2 .

The 8UG an d STEP were the only single -task tests that demonstrated so me po tential to differentiate older persons with MCI from individuals with AD, al though the STEP had a small accuracy to correctly classify both conditions (AUC =0.65 sensitivity=61.5% specificity=56.5%). The composite score of the simple tasks presented a preserved of the AUC values (0.79) with an increase in the specificity (78.2%) when compared to the results of the same test to distinguish healthy subjects from MCI. However, dual-task (seconds, mean velocity and the number of evoked words ) showed a bette r capacity to differentiate older persons with MCI from subjects with AD followed by Delayed Maze Time , but this last one seems to be l ess sensitive and specific (AUC = 0.84 sensitivity = 75.8% specificity= 76.1%). The sit -to-stand test, P lanning Time, as w ell as, the delta -FMT did not reach significance. The significant results for this analysis are shown in Table 3 .

The dual -task tests presented more power to distinguish older persons with AD from their healthy peers. Dual -task seconds showed an AUC of 0.90 with 80.5% sensitivity and 89.5% specificity. However, t here was a decrease in accuracy when using the words (AUC = sensitivity = 81% specificity = 82%). The Floor Maze Test showed different values of accuracy for each s tage of the test; Planning Time (AUC=0.81 sensitivity=78.1% specificity=71.8%), Immediate Maze Time (AUC=0.91 sensitivity=84.8% specificity=84.6%) and Delayed Maze Time (AUC=0.93 sensitivity=94% specificity=84.6%). When compared to MMSE, Delayed Maze Time presented a better sensitivity to differentiate both groups (MMSE=92.3% and DMT=94%). The simple tasks represented by 8UG (time), STEP test and the composite score had an AUC of 0.80, whereas the sit to stand and 8UG (mean velocity) had 0.73 and 0.79 respe ctively. A PCA was initially conducted for the performance variables of the five motor tests with greater AUC in the previous analyses to explore the variance within the dataset. The analys is among the tests revealed that the two-compon ent solution explained a total of 73.9% of the variance, with the first component contributing 54.4% and the second component contributing 19.5%. The tests that showed the higher contributions for the model were DMT, DT and IMT (Supplementary Figure 1). S upplementary Figure 2 also demonstrated the sample distribution within the datas et of PCA by diagnosis, revealing the potential of the tests to discriminate the three conditions.

Additionally, PCA was performed separately for each of these tests along wi th age, sex and education status. When observed through the separate models , a dominant presence pattern of age and education was observed in the first component, whereas sex contributed mainly to the variance of the second component. The se model s accounte d for approximately 70% of the total variance , with the first component corresponding to 45% and the second one 28% (Supplementary Figure 4 to Supplementary Figure 8 ). Supplementary Figure 3 also showed the s chema of the sample distribution wi thin the dataset of PCA by diagnosis take into consideration age, sex and education status . The test that showed the highe st contribution was the composite score, however, the multinomial logistic regression analyses showed that the performance on a composite score, de spite the variance, did not reach statistical significance to explain the diagnosis status ( Table 5). The regression analyses also demonstrated that the diagnostic power of PT, IMT, DMT and DT were not influenced by age and education level. The regression model composed by DMT present ed the largest AUC (94.2%), followed by DT (84.7%) and IMT (78.5%) . On the other hand, IMT time did not ha ve a significant contribution to the diagnos is of healthy and MCI groups ( Table 5).

DISCUSSION In this cross -sectional study, the performances in DT and spatial navigation tests were found to be the best predictors to distinguish among MCI, AD, and healthy older individuals. According to the PCA performed, the combination of the DMT, IMT, PT, DT , and the composite score , account for approximately 73.9% of the sample variance. Moreover, the composite score was found to be strongly influenced by age and sex. The components of DT time, IMT and DMT showed specificity and sensitivi ty values that matched those recommended for the classification of a biomarker (>80%) (El Kadmiri et al. , 2018) to MCI  AD and healthy  AD analyses. The DMT provided greater sensitivity than the MMSE and similar specificity in discriminating individuals with AD from healthy individuals. In contrast, DT time showed good sensitivity and higher specificity than the MMSE for distinguishing individuals with dementia from those with MCI. It is also worth noting that while the MMSE was not able to discriminate b etween healthy older persons and patients with cognitive impairment, the IMT and DMT test s showed an AUC of 0.73.

The MMSE showed a sensitivity of 91.3% and a specificity of 83.3% in discriminating between MCI and AD, whereas the sensitivity and specificit y for distinguishing the healthy and AD groups were 92.3% and 85.7%, respectively. However , unlike motor tests, the results of the MMSE were influenced by the level of education of the sample population. In a previous meta - analysis, Tsoi et al. (2015) show ed that, despite the greater accuracy of the MMSE for the identification of individuals with dementia (sensitivity = 0.81 and specificity = 0.89), the test does not seem to capture the initial stages of cognitive impairment (sensitivity = 0.62 and specific ity = 0.87). Moreover, the MMSE results showed higher levels of heterogeneity due to differences in cut -off values, the methodology used in the assessment and education bias. Almeida, (1998) found that the sensitivity and specificity of MMSE were 84% and 6 0.3% at the cut -off point 23/24, and when schooling was taken into account, the sensitivity and specificity values were 77.8% and 75.4%, respectively. In the same study f or the 19/20 score, the MMSE showed a sensitivity of 80.0% and specificity of 70.9% fo r the diagnosis of d ementia among illiterate older persons . It is also well known that the accuracy of the MMSE for the detection of dementia is also influenced by potential confounders such as ethnic group and dementia type (Tsoi et al. , 2015; Santiago -Bravo et al. , 2019) .
Spatial navigation tests (PT and IMT) showed the best diagnostic accuracy for the identification of patients with MCI, whereas DT proved to be the best test to differentiate older

persons with MCI and AD. It can be speculated that the di fferent outcomes may be due to preservation of attentional resources and visuospatial abilities in the healthy and MCI groups, which may have facilitated better scene -reconstruction and better DMT performances in both groups, as well as, better performance in the DT. DT performances also benefit from the maintenance of mobility between the groups . However, the construction of spatial maps showed impairment , which is a characteristic of MCI , making the spatial navigation component of the PT and IMT more sens itive for differentiation between these two groups. However, the regression analysis demonstrated that IMT performance can be influenced by sex, making PT a better choice of test. A recent study demonstrated that, despite the impaired ability of individual s with MCI to acquire new environmental information, they were able to retain sufficient information that could be used efficiently after a delay. This observation may be related to maintenance of spatial retention capacity in this population (Allison et al., 2016) . Taken together, these results may explain why PT and IMT are more powerful than DMT in discriminating individuals with MCI from their healthy peers.

Both the MCI and AD groups presented impairment in attention skills and visuospatial capacity, a s well as inferior executive function and mobility. However, evidence suggests that FMT performance is not significantly influenced by mobility in individuals with AD (Zanco et al., 2018) ; it can be speculated that DT tests showed better sensitivity in dis tinguishing between the two groups for this reason. It can also be hypothesized that these differences can be accounted for the impairment of executive functions and semantic memory that occur in the disease (Joubert et al. , 2010) , both of which can compro mise the performance in the second task of the DT test (Yogev‐Seligmann et al. , 2008) . Although the logistic regression model showed a contribution of PT performance to MCI and AD diagnosis, the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis of the test results did not demonstrate statistical significa nce in differentiating between the two groups. We speculate that this may be since it is not possible to determine whether the individual is actively planning the route during the test. Due to the disease, older adults with cognitive impairment and especia lly those with AD may no longer be able to plan the route but claim they succeeded to continue the test. In the healthy and AD groups, the DMT provided the best diagnostic accuracy, offering higher sensitivity than the MMSE, with the same values for specificity and a similar AUC. Like in the DT, PT and IMT tests, we did not observe any educational bias in t he DMT results, which further confirms the clinical value of this test for evaluating and tracking the disease. However,

it is important to note that, as seen in previous studies (Hollman et al. , 2011; Holtzer et al. , 2017; Scheuringer e Pletzer, 2017) , spatial navi gation and DT ability were influenced by sex. Despite the composite score showing moderate power for diagnostic accuracy in the ROC curve, the PCA and logistic regression analyses demonstrated that the results of the test are influenced mainly by the intra -sample variance in age and sex. However, when separated, the 8UG and STEP showed an AUC of 0.76 and 0.65 for MCI and healthy individuals, respectively, and 0.78 and 0.80 for the healthy and AD groups, respectively. In addition, many studies have revealed the associations between gait, aerobic capacity decline and dementia (Vidoni et al. , 2012; De Oliveira Silva et al. , 2019) . This could mean that the trajectories of physical decline are different in each stage of the disease and the best approach would be to consider these separately. Furthermore, the results may be influenced by the type of test (the TUG is the most used test to assess mobility and the VO 2 max. test is t he gold standard for evaluation of aerobic capacity). Nevertheless, the DT te sts showed more diagnostic power than the simple -task test, supporting the hypothesis that motor and physical tasks that present with a cognitive demand are more sensitive for differentiating older persons with cognitive decline from healthy individuals.

In general, spatial navigation (PT, IMT and DMT) and DT tests have good diagnostic accuracy for the identification of individuals with cognitive decline. Furthermore, DT time, and the IMT and DMT tests reached specificity and sensitivity values that matched those recommended for the classification of a biomarker. In addition, the performance in these tests was found unaffected by education level.

The limitations of the present study must be considered. These include the small size of our sample and the cross -sectional study design, which impairs the observation of a longitudinal relationship between the decline in motor function and physical capacity and the development of dementia .

CONCLUSION In the present study , we showed that motor/physical tests re present an easy-to-apply and ecological approach to evaluate differences in spatial navigation and dual-task performance of older adults with different cognitive statu ses, contributing as a possible motor biomarker of the disease. Furthermore, the DMT show ed better diag nostic accuracy for differentiating healthy individuals from AD patients, presenting higher sensitivity than the MMSE, with the same values of specificity and similar AUC .

ESTUDO 03

AEROBIC CAPAC ITY CAN INFLUENCE SPATIAL NAVIGATION PERFORMANCE IN HEALTHY AND MCI OLDER ADULTS: A CROSS - SECTIONAL STUDY Jessica Plácido (orcid.org/0000 -0003 -1921 -6672), José Vinicius Ferreira , Felipe de Oliveira 0682 ), Carla Guimarães (orcid.org/0000 -0002 -7835 -5122) , Andréa Nunes de Carvalho (orcid.org/0000 -0002 -8294 -4552 ), Jerson Laks, Andrea Camaz Deslandes (orcid.org/0000 -
Estudo submetido a o Journal of Aging and Phy sical Activity
ABSTRACT:

To investigate the relationship between physical capacity and spatial navigation performance through the floor maze test (FMT) in older adults with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and healthy controls. In this cross -sectional study, 62 older adults were evaluated (healthy =39; MCI=23), both sexes, and aged over 60 years. Spatial navigation was investigated by the FMT, while physical capacity was assessed through the sit -to-stand (STS), 8 -foot up -and-go (8UG) and aerobic steps (STEP) . Mann –Whitney analyses and independent t -tests where used to evaluate the differences between the groups. The relationship between performance in FMT and physical capacity was analyzed through factorial analyses and regression models. The factorial analyses showed that the performance of the physical tests together explained approximately 87% of the intra -sample variability. Regardless of the cognitive decline , mobility (R2=0.22, P ≤0.001) and aerobic capacity ( R2=0.27, P ≤0.001) were associate d with delayed maze time ( DMT). Patients with MCI and healthy older adults with low aerobic capacity were three times more likely to have a poor performance in the DMT stage after controlling for age, sex, and diagnosis (OR=3.1, CI 95%=1.0–9.5, P=0.04). Aerobic capacity can influence spatial navigation performance, not only in patients with MCI but also in healthy older adults. Keywords : Cognitive decline, spatial memory, floor maze test, cardiorespiratory fitness, mobility.

Introduction The World Health Organization (WHO) formulated the concept of intrinsic capacity (IC), described as the composite of all the physical and mental capacities of an individual (WHO , 2015) . The IC is composed of five key domains: cognition, vitality, psychological, sensory and locomotor abilities, which are constituted by gait, balance and strength capacity. Beard et al. (2019) reported that IC score is associated with clinical outcomes such as multimorbidity, cognitive decline and dementia, and can also be related to lo ss of activities of daily living (ADL) and instrumental activities of daily living (IADL), resulting in increased care dependence. According to Dingova et al. (2016) , disorientation in a familiar environment can reflect deficits in different components of daily function. (De Oliveira et al, 2020) also showed that spatial navigation deficit is more intense than cognitive and gait impairment for the diagnosis of patients with dementia who present partial dependence in terms of IADL. Considered as an intermedi ate stage between healthy aging and dementia, mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is characterized by a decline in cognitive function (1.5 standard deviations in specific tests) and functionality preservation (Petersen et al. , 1999) . A meta -analysis of cohort studies with more than five years of follow -up revealed that 38% of MCI cases will progress to dementia (Beard et al, 2009) . This means that the majority of individuals diagnosed with MCI can remain in the pre -dementia stages, which guarantees the preserv ation of autonomy and lower expenses associated with the condition (Association, 2019) . Memory impairment and spatial disorientation are the most frequent symptoms present in patients with MCI (Colombo et al. , 2017) . In a longitudinal study, Verghese et al. (2017) verified that a decline in spatial navigation performance evaluated during four years is associated with a two -fold increase in the risk of healthy elderly people developing MCI. In addition, cross -sectional studies often showed that individuals w ith MCI had significantly impaired spatial navigation ability compared to that of healthy control and dementia patients (Rusconi et al. , 2015; Zanco et al. , 2018) . The relationship between spatial navigation and dementia is mediated by the hippocampus (pla ce cells) and entorhinal cortex (grade cells), areas that are responsible for navigation from the allocentric perspective (object -object). On the other hand, the posterior parietal cortex, especially the precuneus and the inferior parietal lobule, is assoc iated with egocentric navigation (individual -object). This region is also particularly vulnerable to the effects of aging and neurocognitive disorders (Colombo et al. , 2017) .

Some studies have identified impairments in the physical capacity of elderly with MCI and Alzheimer’s disease (AD), such as aerobic capacity, strength, and mobility suggesting the existence of interaction among physical performance, cognitive ability, and the development of dementia (Buracchio et al. , 2010; Noguera et al. , 2019; Plácid o J, 2019; De Oliveira Silva et al., 2020) . According to the subcommittee of the Canadian Consensus Conference on Diagnosis and Treatment of Dementia, physical impairment, especially gait decline, is a non -cognitive phenotype of dementia and can help ident ify peop le at risk for cognitive decline. In addition, the consensus also highlights that motor biomarkers are potentially amenable to treatment, which might in turn delay the onset of cognitive decline (Montero‐Odasso et al. , 2020). In a three -year follow -up pros pective study, Verghese et al. (2014) reported that older adults with cognitive impairment and decreased gait speed, described as motoric cognitive risk syndrome (MCR), have a three -fold increase in the risk of developing dementia. Verghese et al. (2017) also demonstrated the existence of a relationship between the diagnosis of MCR and performance in spatial navigation, showing that healthy older adults with impaired spatial orientation are six times more likely to develop MCR.

The relationship between moto r decline and the progression of cognitive impairment is modulated by alterations in the frontotemporoparietal network, and the basal ganglia, including the dopaminergic nigrostriatal pathway (Buracchio et al. , 2010) . In this sense, aerobic capacity can be an essential component acting in the preservation of executive functions, neural networks, and brain structures, such as the frontal, parietal and temporal cortex (Hayes et al. , 2013 ). Findings in the literature demonstrate the existence of an association between aerobic capacity levels and the preservation of the hippocampus, as well as , the cingulate cortex, prefrontal and parietal areas of patients with AD, MCI and healthy older adults, these results are often translated into better cognitive and execut ive function in this population (Erickson et al., 2009; Erickson et al., 2011; Hayes et al., 2013; Köbe et al., 2016). Teixeira et al (2016) reported a relationshi p between gray matter volume, white matter integrity and aerobic capacity in patients with aM CI, mainly in frontal areas. Zanco et al. (2018) reported a moderate association between aerobic capacity, mobility, and spatial navigation performance in elderly individuals with AD. Despite spatial navigation is a skill that is dependent on visual, propr ioceptive, vestibular, and cognitive interactions (Colombo et al. , 2017) , the relationships among the physical variables of mobility, dynamic balance, and aerobic capacity, that are required for successful navigation in older adults are still unknown. It i s important to note that this knowledge could support low -cost strategies to improve spatial navigation in older adults
with or without cognitive impairment and improve the preservation of functional independence in this population.

Therefore, the purpose of this study was to investigate the contribution of mobility, strength and aerobic capacity to spatial navigation performance in older adults with and without cognitive impairment. Considering the positive relationship between physical capacity and cognit ion, we hypothesized that aerobic capacity, mobility and lower limb strength are associated with spatial navigation in the reported groups.

Methods This study was designed according to the STROBE recommendations (Vandenbroucke et al. , 2007) . The sample con sisted of literate individuals (>60 years) diagnosed as healthy or with mild cognitive impairment by the medical team of the Institute of Psychiatry of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (CDA/IPUB -UFRJ). Psychiatrists made the diagnosis through the structured SCID interview for evaluations of mental disorders according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders - Fourth Edition (DSM -IV). The patients were classified according to their CDR and MMSE scores. Petersen criteria (Petersen et al. , 1999) were used for MCI diagnosis . Individuals without any type of cognitive, psychiatric , or neurological impairment confirmed by a psychiatrist through the same evaluation protocol were considered healthy. The exclusion criteria were previously d escribed in detail (Plácido J, 2019) . All patients signed the written informed consent. This study was approved by the Research Ethics Committee at IPUB -UFRJ, under registration in CAAE: 24904814.0.0000.5263 and it is part of a major research project, enti tled “Efficacy of physical exercise in the treatment of Major Depression, Alzheimer’s Disease and Parkinson’s Disease” Procedures and tests The patients performed the evaluations in three visits. In the first one , they were presented to the research, sig ned the informed consent, performed anthropometric measurements and answered anamnesis and neuropsychological tests. In the second visit a maximal treadmill test to predict VO 2max and assess possible cardiac health problems was applied. On the third visit , physical and spatial navigation tests were performed. Descriptive tests, cognitive and physical assessment

All participants were submitted to descriptive tests to assess the ability to perform instrumental activities of daily living through the Lawton sca le (Lawton e Brody, 1969) , static and dynamic balance using the Berg balance scale (BBS) (Berg et al. , 1992) , and the body mass index -BMI ( Kg/m2). We also evaluated global cognition through MMSE (Folstein et al. , 1975) . The physical capacity was evaluate d through step test (aerobic capacity), 8 -foot up -and- go test (8UG) (mobility) and Sit -to-stand test (STS) ( lower limbs strength). The details of each protocol were previously described (Zanco et al. , 2018) .

Spatial navigation assessment The Floor Maze Te st (FMT) refers to a task that combines spatial navigation with walking and requires the individual to plan a rout ing strategy to move in a two -dimensional maze. The participants are placed at the start point of the maze and receive basic orientations abou t the entrance and the exit. Three stages of the FMT were evaluated: (i) Planning Time (PT), which is the time spent between the receipt of instructions and discovery of the correct way out, excluding the time spent walking; (ii) Immediate Maze Time (IMT), which is the time spent walking between the entry of the maze and the successful exit; and (iii) Delayed Maze Time (DMT), which is the time spent on repetition of the second period, performed after 10 minutes without planning. During this interval, the pa rticipants were not able to maintain visual contact with the maze (Sanders et al. , 2008) .

Statistical analysis The normality and homoscedasticity of the sample were analyzed using Kolmogorov - Smirnov and Levene tests, respectively. The differences between the groups for the variables that presented normal distribution were analyzed by T -independent tests, whereas for the variables that did not present normality Mann -Whitney U tests were performed. We applied Principal Components Analysis (PCA) to explore th e variance and possible associations of the physical and spatial navigation performance inside the sample. The results of this application were based on the combination of the first two components generated. The relationship between FMT components (PT, IMT , DMT) and physical capacity (STEP, 8UG, STS) was analyzed through multiple regression with stepwise model and logistic regression using odds ratio estimates to evaluate the association. The results of the regression analyses were controlled by age, sex an d diagnosis. Only the variables that showed significance in the multiple regression analyses were tested in the logistic model. Statistical analysis was conducted using the SPSS
software® version 2 6.0 (IBM Corporation, New York, USA) and RStudio software v ersion 1.3.1073. The significance level considered was p ≤ 0.05.

Results A total of 101 MCI patients and healthy control were recruited. However, 23 participants were initially excluded due to the lack of interest (n=15), cardiovascular disease (n=5), an d psychiatric comorbidity (n=3). After being evaluated, 20 participants were excluded due to the following reasons: non -completion of the battery of physical tests (n=16) or FMT (n=4). In the end, 58 participants were included in the analyses (Figure 1).

The groups showed a significant differenc e in the STEP (p=0.003), but not in the 8UG (p=0.29) and Sit -to-Stand test (p=0.11). In addition, the performance of the MCI group was significantly impaired in the three stages of the FMT, when compared to the healthy control group (PT: p=0.001; IMT: p=0. 003; DMT: p=0.003), except in the number of errors made during the IMT (p=0.29) and DMT (p=0.06) (Table 2).

PCA was performed to analyze the relationship among the variables within the dataset. Figure 2 shows the resu lts of PCA concerning the first and second principal components (PC1 and PC2). This two-component solution reveals that the physical capacity status accounts for 87.0% of the variance contained in the sample. PC1 refers to 65.0% and PC2 refers to 22.0% of the total variability. Figure 2A displays how much the variables (STEP, 8UG , and STS scores) contribute to each component, showed that STEP and 8UG were the variables that contributed most to the variance of the model, with 37.5% and 35.6% for the PC1 resp ectively . The loading plot (Fig. 2B) presents the direction and length of the vectors, indicating the relationship among them.

Multiple regression analyses indicated an association between mobility, aerobic capacity, and the stages of FMT: IMT (STEP R2=0.12, p≤0.001) and DMT (S TEP R2=0.27, p≤0.001; 8UG R2=0.22, p≤0.001) after control by age, sex , and diagnosis (Table 3). Additionally, the loss of three and four repetitions in the STEP test is associated with a 1 -second increase in the IMT (B=-0.4, p=0.007) and DMT time (B=-0.3, p=0.003) respectively . There was no association between STS and the FMT stages.

The logistic regression analysis showed that even after being controlled by diagnosis, sex and age, individuals with a worse aerobic capacity were three times more likely to have worse performance in DMT stage (OR=3.1, 95%CI=1.0 -9.5, p=0. 04) (Table 4).

Discussion In this study, we aimed to examine how the different components of physical capacity can influence the spatial navigation ability in older adults with and without cognitive impairment. The performance of the MCI group was si gnificantly impaired in the three stages of the FMT when compared to the healthy group. According to the PCA, the physical capacity status of the sample explained approximately 87.0% of the variance present within the data, with the STEP and 8UG tests bein g the variables that contributed the most to the variance of the model. The regression model revealed that mobility contributed 22% to the performance in the DMT stage. Our results also showed that aerobic capacity explained 27% and 12% of the time spent i n completing the IMT and DMT stages, respectively. Furthermore, healthy older adults or those with MCI who presented worse aerobic capacity were three times more likely to have a poor performance in the DMT stage after being controlled for the confounding variables. No relationship was identified between lower limb strength and spatial navigation performance.

Despite the well -known relationship between aerobic capacity and cognition, only one previous study analyzed the influence of aerobic capacity on spat ial navigation. Zanco et al. , (2018) found a moderate correlation between the components of the FMT and the STEP test (PT: r = -0.45; IMT: r = -0.37; DMT: r = -0.44), however, the sample was composed of healthy elderly individuals and patients with AD. The relationship between the STEP test and the IMT stage observed in this study could be related to the effects of aerobic capacity on brain structures, such as the hippocampus and retrosplenial cortex, two important areas involved in the formation and recall of cognitive maps (Hayes et al. , 2013; Kuga et al. , 2018) . Whereas, the DMT stage, due to the need for the ability to recalling the route, may have benefited from the effect of aerobic capacity on the executive functions of older adults (Hayes et al. , 201 3). Increasing aerobic capacity seems to be an excellent strategy for maintaining a healthy brain with preserved memory and executive functions. Müller et al. (2017) , showed that for each increase of 1 -MET in the VO 2max, there is an 8% decrease in the risk of MCI incidence.

Recently, Plácido J et al (2019) reported that older adults with a low aerobic capacity measured by the STEP test have a four -fold increase in the risk of being diagnosed with MCI. In th is sense, it is expected that interventions designed to increase aerobic capacity in healthy older adults can promote spatial navigation preservation and reduce the incidence of MCI in this population.

The relationship between spatial navigation and mobili ty observed in our results can be explained by the path integration of spatial and locomotor information, which depends on a complex network and the use of both allocentric and egocentric frameworks (Colombo et al. , 2017) . The mechanisms of the pathway int egration in the brain are not yet fully understood, although it has been suggested that the creation of this network is mediated by the retrosplenial cortex and the lateral septum (Colombo et al. , 2017) . Nestor et al. (2003) reported hypometabolism and atr ophy in the retrosplenial cortex as a characteristic of individuals with MCI. Furthermore, deficits in gait and postural control are often related to a decline in cognition (De Oliveira Silva et al. , 2019; Sant’anna et al. , 2019) . Thus, it can be speculate d that the contribution of mobility to the DMT stage represents an impairment of the integration mechanisms involved in spatial navigation rather than specific framework deterioration . Despite the importance of lower limb strength for dynamic balance, func tional independence, and cognition in older adults (De Oliveira Silva et al. , 2019; Sant’anna et al. , 2019; Gray et al. , 2020) there are conflicting reports of the relationship between this variable and cognitive decline in the literature. When evaluating the differences in the lower limb function in healthy older adults, and patients with MCI and AD, Eggermont et al. (2010) did not find a significant difference among the groups. Ohsugi et al. (2014) reported similar results in MCI patients and healthy con trols, although the authors highlighted the influence of attention on the performance of the test. However, some studies have shown a relationship between cognition and lower limb strength as well as the positive influence of strength training and cognitio n. In a randomized controlled trial , Da Silveira Langoni et al. (2019) reported that six months of a multimodal exercise intervention improved global cognition and the performance in the STS among older individuals with MCI. Furthermore, in a study of Chin ese community - dwelling older adults, Yang et al. (2018) demonstrated that individuals with low repetitions in the STS were more likely to have cognitive impairment.
Our results corroborate previous studies that evaluated spatial navigation in older indiv iduals with subjective memory complaints and AD using the same protocol, which showed

that the time spent in completing the FMT increased with the severity of cognitive impairment. Tangen et al. (2015) found a mean completion time of 19.5 seconds (s) for t he PT stage of the test, 17.0 s for the IMT, and 13.0 s for the DMT in older individuals with cognitive complaints. In an investigation of the performance of the elderly with AD in the FMT, Zanco et al. (2018) reported a mean completion time of 104.2 s for the PT stage, 87.4 s for the IMT, and 85.6 s for the DMT. In the present study, patients with MCI had mean completion times of 77 s, 29 s, and 23 s for the PT, IMT, and DMT stages, respectively. These results support the hypothesis that there a continuous decline in spatial navigation during the progression of dementia, which can be detected even in the asymptomatic stages of the disease by using the FMT. Moreover, the association of gait and aerobic capacity with spatial navigation ability could mean that spatial navigation also reflects changes in intrinsic capacity.

The present study has some limitations that should be considered. Although aerobic capacity is associated with the best performance in FMT, the cross -sectional experimental design does not al low a cause -and-effect relationship to be established. Also, aerobic capacity was not evaluated through measurement of VO 2max, which is considered the gold standard for inference of cardiovascular condition. However, the STEP test and the FMT are both easy -to- apply and ecological evaluations, which facilitate the extension of these results for clinical use. Notwithstanding the extensive literature on motor -cognitive interaction in cognitive impairment, this is the first study to verify a possible influence of physical variables on the performance of spatial navigation in older adults with MCI. Future studies should evaluate the potential of long -term maintenance of aerobic capacity to positively influence the relationship between the decline in spatial navig ation and diagnosis in the early stages of dementia. Conclusion Healthy elderly adults and patients with MCI with low aerobic capacity are three times more likely to develop spatial navigation impairment. Moreover, the performance in the FMT was also influ enced by mobility.

6 – CONSIDERAÇÕES FINAIS A presente dissertação teve co mo objetivo inves tigar os preditores físicos do desempenho na navegação espacial em idosos saudáveis, pacientes com CCL e DA . Além disso, buscou -se avaliar a acurácia do F MT em diferenciar esses três grupos . No estudo 01, a partir de uma revisão sistemática e meta -analise, com o objetivo primário de comparar o desempenho entre idosos com CCL, demência e saudáveis, e com o objetivo secundário de identificar quais as características inserid as nos testes melhor diferenciam esses grupos. No estudo 02, onde o objetivo principal foi investigar o potencial dos testes motores, de dupl a tarefa e do FMT em diferenciar idosos com DA e CCL de seus pares saudáveis. E no estudo 03 , a partir de um desenho de corte transversal, cujo o objetivo foi investigar a relação entre a mobilidade, capacidade aeróbica, equ ilíbrio, força e o desempenho na navegação espacial através do FMT . Tais estudos reforçaram a hipótese de que o comprometimento na capacidade de navegação espacial é um biomarcador do envelhecimento patol ógico, principalmente em idosos com CCL e DA. O estudo de revisão demonstrou que dentre as habilidades espaciais a navegação alocêntrica e a capacidade de integração de caminho são as mais comprometid as durante o curso do comprometimento cognitivo. Os resultados também ressaltam a importância do deslocamento nos protocolos que visam investigar a navegação espacial em idosos, e a capacidade do FMT para diferenciar idosos saudáveis de idosos com comprome timento cognitivo. No estudo 02 , extendemos esses achados, demonstrando a existência de um comprometimento significativo da navegação espacial entre idosos saudáveis, com CCL e DA sendo identificado em todas as etapas do FMT . Esses resultados corroboram o reportado por Monacelli et al, (2003 ) e Cushman et al, (2008) ao avaliarem a navegação espacial entre os 3 grupos através do HGT e MRMT . Entretanto , como observado no estudo de metanalise (estudo 01), ambos os testes possuem tamanhos de efeito menores do q ue o FMT para diferenciar idosos com declínio cognitivo . Os resultados do estudo 02 também demonstraram que as etapas do FMT possuem uma alta acu rácia para diferenciar não apenas idosos com DA, mas tamb ém os individuos nos estágios pre -demenciais da doença com o IMT . Os resultados mostraram uma acurácia moderada para identificar pacientes com CCL. Já o DMT apresentou uma maior sensibilidade para identificar pacientes com DA do que o MEEM, além disso, diferente do MEEM, o FMT demonstrou não ser influenciado pelo nível de escolaridade dos idosos . Assim como em trabalhos anteriores (Breton et al., 2018; Tsoi et al., 2015) , o MEEM não foi ca paz

de identificar os idosos com CCL . Ademais um outro ponto a ser destacado é que o FMT apresenta todas as característica s encontradas na met a-analise que melhor diferenciam os grupos com declínio cognitivo dos idosos saudáveis, tais como, prese nça de deslocamento, foco ambiental, e seu desfecho é medido pelo tempo . Esses dados destacam a importância de se avaliar a navegaçã o espacial em idosos, e suportam a inclusão do FMT nas baterias de testes de rastreio cognitivo como estratégia para aumentar o potencial diagnóstico das mesmas . No estu do 03 podemos observar a importância da s variáveis físicas, tais como , a mobilidade e a capacidade aeróbica para um a navegação espacial de sucesso. O modelo de regressão demonstrou que cerca de 22% do desempenho no DMT pode ser explicado pela mobilidade dos pacientes. Cabe ressaltar que durante a marcha são fornecidas as informações sensori ais a cerca da distância da rota, promovendo a atualização do mapa cognitivo. Esses achados corroboram os resultados da nossa metanalise e mais uma vez reforçam o papel da capacidade de integração de caminho para a navegação espacial, assim como a necessid ade dos protocolos utilizarem o movimento durante a avaliação para uma maior acurácia do teste. Apesar das relações entre a marcha, capacidade aeróbica e navegação espacial ainda serem pouco investigadas, estudos demonstram a existência de uma associação e ntre o declínio físico/mot or e cognitivo (Buracchio et al. , 2010; Noguera et al. , 2019; Plácido J, 2019; De Oliveira Silva et al. , 2020 ). De acordo com Dumurgier et al, (2017) idosos com um declínio anual de 0.20 m/s na marcha possuem 50% mais chances de desenvolverem demência num período de 7 anos . Parâmetros específicos da marcha, tais como, o comprimento e o tempo da passada também estão associados com uma maior prevalência de demência , principalmente com a DA (Darweesh et al. , 2019). Especula -se que e ssa relação aconteça devido ao comprometimento de áreas frontais do cérebro em virtude da deposição de proteína beta amiloide e lesões na substância branca nessas regiões ( Laat et al., 2011; Verlinden et al. , 2016 ). Enquanto a associação da marcha com a n avegação espacial está possivelmente relacionada a integração de estruturas responsáveis pela ordenação de informação egocêntricas e alocêntricas, como o córtex retroesplenial, núcleo caudado, precuneus e áreas parietais posteriores (Mahmood et al., 2009 ; Li W et al., 2021 ). No est udo 3 também identificamos que idosos c om uma baixa performance no teste do STEP possuem 3 vezes mais chances de apresentar um pior desempenho na etapa do DMT, indicando uma contribuição da capacidade aeróbica especialmente para a retenção das informações espaciais. Esses dados estão possivelmente associados com a relação entre a capacidade aeróbica e a manutenção de estruturas cerebrais

como o córtex frontal e parietal , que se traduz em uma melhor função executiva e atenção (Hayde s et al., 2013; Vesperman et al., 2018 ; Cole et al., 2020 ; Mekari et al., 2020 ). Os estudos desenvolvidos nessa dissertação também levantam a hipótese de que o uso de intervenções motoras e físicas, tais como o exercício físico, possam auxiliar na manutençã o da navegação espacial através do efeito sobre o aumento da capacidade aeróbica, mobilidade e do equilibro. Todavia, reconhecemos que ainda existe a necessidade de pesquisas que utilizem o FMT em populações com outro tipo de demência que não a DA e de des enhos que incluam uma maior amostra e tempo de acompanhamento. Além disso, os resultados da presente dissertação destacam que o tempo de planejamento do FMT necessita de uma maior investigação, visando aparatos/estratégias que auxiliem na confirmação efeti va do planejamento da rota, acreditamos que desenvolvimento de tais métodos possa promover um aumento da acurácia do teste, especificamente, na diferenciação de idosos com CCL e DA . Por fim, levando em consideração a já conhecida associação entre a capacid ade aeróbica , parâmetros da marcha e demência, futuros estudos devem investigar a relaç ão longitudinal entre essas variáveis com o declínio na navegação espacial e a incidência de transtornos cognitivos em idosos.

7 - CONCLUSÃO O desempenho na navegação espacial demonstrou ser sensível às alterações cognitivas decorrentes do processo de comprometimento cognitivo e DA. O FMT apresentou uma boa capacidade de detectar tais déficits, apresentando alta acurácia e sensibilidade para diferenciar idosos com dife rentes estágios de declínio cognitivo . Além disso , verificamos que a capacidade de navegação espacial está associada com a capacidade física, principalmente com a manutenção dos níveis de capacidade aeróbica.

TERMO DE CONSENTIMENTO LIVRE E ESCLARECIDO Projeto de Pesquisa EFICÁCIA DO EXERCÍCIO FÍSICO NO TRATAMENTO DA DEPRESSÃO MAIOR, DOENÇA DE ALZHEIMER E DOENÇA DE PARKINSON. Universidade Federal d o Rio de Janeiro Av. Venceslau Braz, n° 95, Botafogo, Rio de Janeiro.

Eu, acima identificado, estou sendo formalmente convidado a fazer parte, como voluntario, do estudo intitulado “EFICÁCIA DO EXERCÍCIO FÍSICO N O TRATAMENTO DA DEPRESSÃO MAIOR, DOENÇA DE ALZHEIMER E DOENÇA DE PARKINSON”. Estou ciente que para minha participação será necessário ler e assinar este documento, no qual concordo formalmente com a minha participação em todas as etapas da pesquisa. Estou ciente que estudo tem como objetivo avaliar o efeito do exercício físico no tratamento de doenças mentais (Depressão, Alzheimer e Parkinson) através de parâmetros eletrofisiológicos, neuropsicológicos, funcionais e sintomas de doença. Tais resultados serão associados a questões de saúde pública como risco de quedas, perda de mobilidade funcional, quantidade de internações, uso de medicamentos, recorrência e/ou evolução do transtorno.
